Jeff Clune wrote:
>
> There is an ambiguity in English (and probably most other languages) in the
> terms used here. We think of learning across evolutionary time (where the
> genome changes) and learning within a life (with no genomic change). The
> same can be said of the word 'adapting' and its synonyms.
>
> I prefer to use the word 'intralife' and contrast it with 'interlife.' Using
> this terminology, BP is intralife and EC (evolutionary computation) is
> generally interlife (unless evolution evolves the capacity for intralife
> learning, or is explicitly given it).
>   

With regards to that later point look up 'epigenetics' on wikipedia. An 
example of this in the NEAT world would be to run BP on evolved ANN's 
and to then store the discovered connection weights back into the genome.

Colin
